name: Mai @Almond&Fig
bio: I cook to remember the place I came from Palestine & to pass that connection on to my children | Chicago | Palestine 💔🇵🇸🍉🗝️Creator #aprilisforarabfood

social_posts.post_text:
Growing up we didn’t necessary drink hot chocolate in the winter. It was often a warm cup of sahlab made by my teta or my father, served as a night cap. A thick, and milky creamy drink that’s always garnished with specks of cinnamon, coconut shavings and some nuts. 
sahlab is a powder that is derived from the tubers of orchids which are dried and ground up into flour to be used in drinks and sweets. It’s what give booza (Arabic ice cream) that iconic stretchy texture. Sahlab as a drink is very popular in the Levante region, Turkey, Iran and also Egypt, particularly during the cold winter months. In Jerusalem  where I grew up, and all over Palestine, sahlab is sold on every street corner.  The call by the street vendors to buy sahlab in the winter after school is a memory that warms both the heart and the body. 
Pure Sahlab or salep powder is super hard to find, so cornstarch is often used as a substitute to make this thick and slightly stretchy drink.
Matcha and mastic sahlab is just a festive spin on this very popular treat to mark the beginning of the holidays and perhaps the cold winter season.

The holiday season has begun. I love to entertain and celebrate all while keeping in mind that the holidays are about being together with the ones you love most. When you get something luxurious it’s almost effortless to entertain. I love to serve things that are simple, familiar,  but also unexpected with a touch of festive and indulgence. This way I don’t need to worry about the perfect holiday outfit, best music play list, spotless house or kids running all over the place. 

Savory Atayef Asafeeri 
These little stuffed semolina pancakes like, are slightly sweet and delicate. They make for a perfect canvas for a swirl of my herb Labaneh topped with buttery caviar. The flavor combo is a rich, slightly sweet, yet very savory, and a smooth bite. 
smoked trout Roe with bright orange pearls that have a full pop. has a subtle smoky finish from being smoked on apple and cherry wood chips. and the imperial golden osetra With its glittering gold hue and decadent flavor. The combo of this is definitely a party in your mouth. 
I’m celebrating #12DaysOfCaviar with @thecaviarco these mini little atayef are perfect for a holiday brunch or a cocktail party. Each little bite is like a mini scoop filled with herb Labaneh and topped with buttery and creamy caviar. Check out all the holiday deals and recipes on thecaviarco.com & get your own jar to recreate and gather family and friends this holiday season.

Have you heard of #Burbara? The wheat berry pudding? Chef Mai Kakish from @almondandfig will teach you how to make it during #MyBigFatPalestinianChristmas happening tomorrow at 5 PM EST! Join us for a time filled with live music, delicious food and lots of solidarity with 🇵🇸 refugees. 

Click on link in bio for free tickets.

It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas .. 
my home is perfumed with Cardamom and Date molasses cookies 
These cookies are inspired by winter in the desert and my friend majed from @thecinnaman who’s an amazing baker. find the recipe on his blog. I substituted fennel for cardamom. The sweet and caramel like flavor of the date molasses works so well with the fragrant cardamom seeds. The cookies have a slight crispy exterior but chewy and soft centers. For more holiday cookie inspo check out my friend  @cosetteskitchen #virtualcookieparty2022

Shattah & Labaneh Hot Chicken Dip 

My kids have been obsessed with this dip that I wanted  to share it with you. In hopes it’s perfect time for your new years gathering. Its pretty zesty and comes together in 30 minutes. This dip is my spin on Buffalo chicken with ingredients that are always in my Arab Pantry. Shattah is a delicious spicy pepper condiment similar to chili sauce. It’s  used in sandwiches, dips, salsas etc. This condiment combines just a few simple ingredients to create a sauce that’s a rich, spicy and vibrant. 

Recipe 

Mix 4 ounces softened cream cheese and 1/2 cup each Labaneh, Monterey Jack and Shattah, add 1/4 cup scallions. A squeeze of lemon juice is optional. fold in 2 cups shredded rotisserie chicken. Salt & pepper to taste. Butter a cast iron or a small baking dish, add the chicken mixture sprinkle with 1/2 cup more cheese and bake at 425 degrees F until bubbly, about 20 minutes. Top with more scallions and Aleppo pepper flakes. Serve hot with celery sticks and crackers. If you are lucky get @luluscrackers amazing Shattah crackers for the ultimate Palestinian dip experience. Happy New Years dear friends. Keep it spicy ❤️

Rumman رمان is the Arabic word for pomegranates. 
بدي افرط الرمانات 
My grandmother would announce after lunch 
تعالو تحلو come back for dessert 

Teta would set a  stainless steel bowl in her veranda right off the kitchen, to peel pomegranates. she would peel so many she would stain her fingers and her apron. ‘Rumman’ is way more than a fruit. It is a poetry word it’s full of emotions and illustrations. It’s often referenced in literature and songs. Images of Rumman are often handcrafted on palestinian embroidery, ceramics and art pieces. Growing up we had a few pomegranate trees in our garden. Its ruby fruits hang like an ornament on a Christmas tree. 
Teta served the  pomegranate jewels with a sprinkling of sugar on top For a simple dessert 
This  bowl of fresh pomegranates reminds me of winter of my home in Palestine and my Teta. See tetas original bowl on my story 💔

Our Palestinian kitchen is so diverse and is influenced by the geography of the land.  Rumanieh or حبة رمان comes from the Arabic word Ruman رمان which means pomegranates. Is a slightly tangy dish of stewed lentils and eggplants. It has deep roots in the coastal towns of Lydda and Jaffa, where my sister in law Abeer is from, and where I first had this dish. When Palestinians were displaced from Jaffa and Lydda in the Nakba of 1948 many went to Gaza, Ramallah and Jerusalem where this recipe is now popular. People brought their recipes and stories with them. Rummaniyeh is one such recipe, this delicious humble stew traveled with Palestinians around the world and is built from memories of the people that once lived in Jaffa and Lydda. 
The recipes they brought with them became stories in themselves. These recipes are evidence of identity and existence of the old villages and cities  of Palestine.
This recipe is adapted from my sister in law Abeer whose family now lives in Ramallah and my friends joudie @palestineonaplate and Hani @hani.elfar.7 who document their grandmothers/family recipes from lydda and Jaffa. 

Rumanieh is Best enjoyed at room temperature with charred taboon bread, olives, fresh veggies and herbs.

The Palestinian cuisine relies heavily on what the land produces. The food is delicious and seasonal.
Fall in Palestine begins with the olive harvest and the production of golden olive oil. And right around the corner in the heart of winter is the beloved citrus season.
This lemon and olive oil cake is tribute to winters in Palestine, and to me longing for the home where I grew up.
Bright and refreshing lemons, fruity olive oil, Creamy yogurt and earthy mountain thyme are then mixed together to make this simple and moist loaf. 
When I left Palestine as a young student, I left pieces of my childhood with the olive trees, the blossoming citrus & lemon trees that crowned my grandfather’s garden. My father currently cares for the garden and takes so much pride with every blossoming season. My father sent me photos of the garden that evoked my memory and heightened my longing to my home. 
A lemon loaf to remember winters in Palestine, to honor the olive and lemon trees that my grandfather planted, and to always hold my beloved home in Palestine so close to my heart. 
Full recipe on my website link in profile 
https://www.almondandfig.com/post/2020/01/15/lemon-loaf-with-thyme-yogurt-olive-oil

We have been missing the sun for the past few weeks in this part of the world. So I am looking for recipes that are full of color and flavor to brighten the gloomy winter days. And when pomegranates are in season they will definitely be the star of my recipes as they are enjoyed in so many ways at my home. 

Pomegranates & Sumac Glazed Chicken 
When I saw this recipe in Hanadi’s book #mediterranea @hanadykitchen I knew I had to try it. The sweet and sour glaze from the fresh pomegranates juice, molasses, lemon, garlic and sumac touch on so many sweet and sour notes making for a delicious and moist chicken. 
“Fruit Marinades and sauces made from fruit juices have been used for cooking meats since ancient times, The combination of sweet and sour was especially prevalent in the Levant during the Middle Ages, in dishes such as Lamb stews with quince or orange juice were common as hanadi mentions”. The fresh pomegranates fruit juice in this recipe adds depth, sweetness and a beautiful color that brightens any day. Thank you Hanadi for this brilliant recipe ❤️

1 whole chicken (3-4 pounds), cut into 8 pieces*
2 tablespoons olive oil
2 tablespoons pomegranate molasses 
1 cup pomegranate juice
juice of 1 lemon
2 tablespoons tomato paste
1 tablespoon sumac spice
good grinding freshly ground black pepper
1 Tsp salt 
4 garlic cloves, coarsely chopped
4 sprigs fresh thyme
1 red onion, thinly sliced
pomegranate seeds, for garnish

My heart, it beets for you 
Oceans that crash along the shore
Return to calmer waves across the sea
A moment of clarity
No matter what the future holds
It’s you my heart beats for 🇵🇸❤️

Orange and beets salad with a citrus, orange blossom vinaigrette

Ingredients

	•	3-4  oranges, peeled and sliced or segmented 
	•	1 pomegranate seeded 
	•	3-4 roasted beets, peeled & sliced 
Micro greens or fresh herbs (optional) 
Dressing: 
	•	1/4 cup (2 fl. oz./60 ml) extra-virgin olive oil
	•	Juice of one lemon 
	•	Juice of one blood orange 
	•	1 tsp sumac 
	•	1/2 Tsp orange blossom water (trust me) 
	•	Sea salt and freshly ground pepper

Assemble, that’s it

As I turned the corner on 95th street here it was a little corner store in the south suburbs of Chicago. I was greeted by the palestinian flag on the sign and a picture of shireen abu Akleh. As I walked in i was welcomed by the intense smell of baked bread, spices, fried falafel and fresh mint. These little dukan bodega, halal deli, or that little spice or sweets shop,  serve as a cultural pillar of immigrant communities. They help us preserve and celebrate our cultural traditions and customs. They work hard to source hard-to-find ingredients or products that tastes and smells like home. Today I scored a bundle of one of my favorite winter greens khoubezeh 

Khoubezeh also known as (Malva/Common Mallow)

Khoubezeh  is an important wild winter plant. It’s a delicious and nutritious dish that is neither sold in vegetable stores nor grown in nurseries, but is often harvested in the winter and early spring from the hills, and valleys of Palestine.  It’s cooked so many different ways in the Palestinian kitchen but the simple sauté with onions in golden olive oil and a burst of fresh lemons at the end is my favorite of course enjoyed with warm charred khoubez (bread). 

If you can’t find khoybezeh you can cook any leafy green the same way such as dandelion, kale, or swisschard.
Come shop inside the store with me on my stories ❤️

Orange and walnut cake 
A simple cake with no frosting and no fuss, just slice and enjoy with a cup of coffee or tea for the weekend. It has just the right balance of sweetness, bright citrus notes from the orange.  crumbly walnuts and walnut oil lace the cake with earthy notes. 

Prep time: 15 min 
Total time: 1 hour 
Serves: 6-8

3/4 cup sugar 
Zest of one orange 
2 large eggs, at room temperature 
1/2 cup walnut oil @fresh_vintage_farms 
1 tsp orange extract 
3/4 cup walnut  milk or any milk of your choice 
1 cup AP flour 
3/4 cup walnut flour (see note) 
1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1/4 teaspoon of salt 

Directions: 
1. Preheat oven to 375F. Line a 9-inch cake pan with a circle of parchment paper and brush sides and bottom with a bit of oil.
2. In a bowl, add the sugar and orange zest and mix together with your fingers to infuse the orange, add in the eggs and whisk. Add milk, orange extract and oil. Whisk together until smooth.
3. In a separate bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients: flour, walnut flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Add the wet  ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix just until it’s combined. Don’t over-mix.
4. Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan.
5. Bake the cake until golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean, about 35-45 min.
6. Let the cake cool in the pan until cool enough to handle about half an hour.
7. Invert the cake onto a cooling rack and let it cool completely before slicing. 
8. Serve with whipped cream flavored with orange, or honeyed Greek yogurt, a dusting of confectioners sugar and orange segments. 

Recipe note: To make walnut flour: 
Place walnuts in the food processor, and process until it reaches a small crumble. Be careful that you don’t over-process you will end up with walnut butter.

It’s starting to look like spring in the produce isle 

Spring Fava beans, Labaneh and mint 
ربيع يا فول، لبنة، وفريش يا نعنع 
Enjoy the fresh flavors of spring in this delicious flat bread. Labaneh is super creamy with a slight tang but once it’s baked, the flavor intensifies and almost becomes feta cheese like. To me Fava beans are one of spring’s most coveted ingredients, and I have so many favorite ways of preparing them. Their bright green color,  delicate and buttery flavor pairs so well with refreshing mint. 
Labaneh spread: 
1/2 cup Labaneh 
1 garlic clove, crushed 
1/2 teaspoon dried mint, crumbled 
1 tablespoon lemon juice 
Zest of one lemon 
1/2 Tsp of sea salt 

For the fava: 
1/2 cup shelled fava beans

2-3 sprigs of fresh mint 

To prepare fava beans, remove them from their pods. Then, blanch the beans in boiling water for 1-2 minutes and immediately transfer them to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking process. Once they are cool, use your fingers to peel off the outer skins of the beans, revealing the bright green color. 
 *not an ad just joy to find lactose free Labaneh @karoundairies so all members of my family can enjoy 💚

Making #Shishbarak with your mama and Teta has got to be one of your favorite memories 💕 The wonderful Mai Kakish and her daughter Sophia will be making the lamb dumplings dipped in warm yogurt sauce on #ArabMothersDay Tuesday 3/21 at 7:30 pm EST. Get your free tickets by clicking on link in bio.

Despite the injustice, and all the ache in my beloved falastine. The brutal oppression won’t stop us. We are people that love life, we deserve to celebrate and worship freely. Kaek & mamoul a symbolic treat of Easter in Palestine. 

Both my grandmothers often prepared the Easter cookies. They are usually made a few days before Easter, then stored in tins to be served to guests and family on Easter Sunday. Plates full of kaek and mamoul are often exchanged among neighbors and relatives each taking pride in the texture, and presentation of their cookies. Everyone takes pride in their family recipe. The cookies are made with fine semolina, and the best sweet butter you can find. The results are a delicious and very crumbly cookies. They are often stuffed with dates, walnuts or pistachios, flavored with mastic (a sundried resin that exudes from the bark of a Mediterranean tree), and mahlab, (a spice made from the seeds of a species of cherry), orange blossom and rosewater. The traditional recipe of my family is up on my website. But today i made a Syrian mamoul cookie that my Syrian friend Rana first introduced me to. This Syrian mamoul cookie is filled with sweet cheese, and unlike it’s date cousin this cookies is served warm and topped with a sprinkling of powdered sugar or scented syrup. The variations of our recipes, traditions  and techniques are the beauty of our Arab cuisine as it travels across borders. Happy Easter

استكشف الرحلة الآسرة لتراث الطهي في القدس. نخوض في وصفات الجدة العزيزة والأطباق التقليدية التي تجسد جوهر المدينة. اكتشف كيف توثق هذه المبادرة النسيج الغني للقصص وتؤكد على أهمية الهوية الثقافية. انضم إلينا في ندوة ملهمة عبر الإنترنت حيث نحتفل بالنكهات التي تربطنا بالماضي. لا تفوت هذه الفرصة لتكون جزءًا من الحفاظ على تراث الطهي في القدس.

Explore the captivating journey of Jerusalem's culinary heritage. We delve into dear grandmother's recipes and traditional dishes that capture the essence of the city. Discover how this initiative documents the rich tapestry of stories and emphasizes the importance of cultural identity. Join us for an inspiring webinar as we celebrate the flavors that connect us to the past. Don't miss this opportunity to be part of preserving Jerusalem's culinary heritage.

Don't miss this opportunity to gain insights into the significance of cultural identity and the power of preserving culinary heritage. Thank you to everyone who joined us, and a special thanks to Mai Khader Kakish for sharing her story. Stay tuned for more inspiring content and future webinars! 

 WebinarVideo #CulinaryHeritage 
 # #hanashamscent# #hana #Jerusalem #urbanheritage #city PreservingTraditions #Inspiration

Asparagus in palestine is called “hlayoun” هليون a perennial spring flowering plant that belongs to the lily family. 
Asparagus hasn’t been cultivated in Palestinian agriculture . It grows on its own wild and free. 

‎هليون grows wild espically in Gaza and many palestinian villages. It starts growing in late winter, in narrow places under trees,  rocks, by cactus plants and stone fences. And It is foraged in the spring time when the stalks are most tender 

If you are lucky to find it at the local market it’s often pretty expensive due to the intense labor 
Of Foraging for it. As it grows often by cactus plants and covered in thorns which makes it a sweet treat in this traditional palestinian dish of fried tender asparagus هليون with eggs and garlic in golden olive oil.

Za’atar lemon Iced Tea 

The pungent green herb “za’atar” gives this summer drink an earthy, savory yet floral notes. The herb grows wild in the hills of Palestine, and it tastes like a combination of oregano, marjoram, summer savory and thyme. So any of these herbs can be substituted to make this drink.

Za’atar lemon iced tea is a refreshing beverage that’s a twist on the classic,  offering a savory and aromatic taste experience. To maximize the herbaceous flavor of za’atar, first infuse the za’atar leaves in the simple syrup, and also into a brewed tea of your choice, then chill, and serve over ice with lemon juice and lemon slices.

This herbal infusion offers a refreshing and herbaceous flavor profile, perfect for those hot summer days.

No-Churn Mastic & Kamardin (apricot fruit leather) Ice Cream

One of my favorite summer fruits are apricots. And during its very short season it’s enjoyed in so many ways. Kamardin is just apricot paste dehydrated and made into a fruit leather. It’s sticky to the touch, bright orange, sweet and a little bit sour. Kamardin was originally made to preserve the season’s most beloved fruit,  so it can be enjoyed throughout the year. Kamardin originated from Syria where the variety of apricots most suitable for kamardin was first grown. This particular package is from Palestine where it’s been made by the Camel factory since 1941. made purely out of apricots, sugar and a bit of olive oil. 
You don’t need any fancy ice cream tools to make this no-churn ice cream. The cream base flavored with the slightly piney mastic compliments the intense floral fruit flavor of Kamardin. Kamardin is available at ethnic Arab stores all over the country. Check out my stories for tips and more info. It’s a treat hope you give it a try.

If you love Italian panna cotta, you need to try Mahalabia!!! My friend Mai @almondandfig shared her simple mahalabia recipe that is an iconic milk pudding known throughout the Middle East and parts of the Mediterranean with variations from Egypt to Lebanon, Greece, and Turkey. It is a smooth and creamy dessert pudding that takes just a handful of ingredients you already have on hand (milk, sugar, cornstarch, and if you like, a little rose water…I love it with rose water). Muhalabia is served cold, so it’s perfect for the summertime especially with a little strawberry on top! Mai’s recipe is a must-try! Ingredients:

For The Milk Pudding:

▢ 4 cups whole milk or almond milk
▢ ½ cup 
Zgranulated sugar
▢ ½ cup cornstarch
▢ 1 teaspoon rosewater
▢ 2 tablespoons unsalted shelled pistachios, crushed, for garnish

If you want to add the Macerated Strawberries topping, you’ll need:

▢ 1 pound strawberries, stems removed and quartered
▢ 2 tablespoons sugar
▢ ½ teaspoon rosewater

The full recipe is on The MediterraneanDish (dot) com, you can tap the link in profile @themediterraneandish 👆 to get there. Follow for more easy recipes. 
📸 by the gorgeous @mariamhamdy 
.

.
.
.

Macaroni bi al Laban معكرونة باللبن 
Yogurt pasta with garlic scapes pesto 
~ A 15 minutes power lunch perfect for this hot weather 

Growing up pasta was called macaroni معكرونة and it was cooked only three ways. With a tomato ragu sauce then baked to perfection, with fresh yogurt and mint in the summer, divine.  and with butter and cinnamon sugar for a quick dessert lol 
I could eat the first two for the rest of my life but the cinnamon pasta long retired since my school, stay up all night days. 
pasta with yogurt is super refreshing, high in protein and requires minimum steps. by the time the pasta boils you are pretty much ready to eat. Garlic scapes are in season for a short time so I made em into a pesto of sort. Definitely substitute with chives or just throw in a garlic clove and a sprinkling of dried mint. Toss with the hot pasta, garnish with fried pine nuts and enjoy. #childhood #lunches

I spent the morning trying to figure out how in the world I lost a week worth of work when my word doc crashed down 😩 wanting nothing to do with my computer, I went for some garden therapy. To my delight i found a large and beautiful heirloom  zucchini variety that I grew for the first time. 
My friend Shayma @spicespoon posted her pakora recipe during Ramadan and I have been wanting to make it ever since. @noreenwasti made her pakora with shredded zucchini so i found the right recipe to fix my mood. Zucchini, blossoms, and cilantro laced pakoras. These are crazy delicious specked with cumin and coriander and a little jalapeño and Aleppo pepper for some spice. Used @spicespoon recipe because don’t mess with dishes that are rooted in deep culinary traditions. Pakoras are an integral part of Indian and Pakistani street food culture. And hail from ancient origins to regional variations. 
I might not retrieve my word doc but nothing a crispy vegetable fritter bubbling in a hot oil bath can’t fix.

Fig, anise seeds, and walnut fruit crumble

Flavors Inspired by my grandfather’s Garden and his most luscious fig trees and Tetas (grandmother) fig jam that she often made in late summer when figs were at the peek of their sweetness for her mooneh (pantry). Teta’s fig jam was one of her favorites. always a staple on her breakfast table, and all throughout the year. 
Figs in Arabic are called teen,  when baked they get jammy and add an intense sweet flavor and soft floral notes. anise in Arabic is called yansoon, it adds a subtle sweetness and a delicate licorice flavor. The olive oil makes this crumble rich and compliments the figs real well

With this teen and yansoon crumble I  reimagined flavors that take me home to Palestine, to the times we gathered around Teta’s breakfast table and played around in Sidos garden underneath the fig trees. 

INGREDIENTS
FOR THE FILLING:
* 6 to 7 cups fig fruit, halved 
* 1 cup walnut 
* 1/2 cup granulated sugar,
* 2 tbls freshly squeezed lemon juice
* 
FOR THE CRUMBLE TOPPING:
* 1 cup ap flour
* 1/2 cup walnut flour 
* 1/2 cup packed light or dark brown sugar 
* 1 Tsp anise seeds, crushed 
* 2 tbls raw sesame seeds 
* 1/4 teaspoon salt
* 4 tbls olive oil and 4 tbls unsalted butter, cubed & at room temperature

INSTRUCTIONS
PreHeat oven to 375°F and butter a baking dish. set aside.
- remove the stems off the figs and cut them in half or quarters depending on their size. In a bowl gently toss the figs, and walnuts with sugar, & lemon juice. 
- Transfer the fruit filling into the prepared baking dish.
for  the crumble topping. 
- In a bowl Whisk the flour, walnut flour, sugar, anise seeds, sesame seeds and salt together in a large bowl. Add the olive oil and the cubed butter, Using your fingers, work the butter and olive oil into the dry ingredients until it resembles wet crumbs.
- Scatter the crumble evenly all over the fruit. 
- Bake until the fruit juices are bubbling around the edges of the baking dish and the topping is golden, 30 to 35 minutes.
Serve with a vanilla bean ice cream or honeyed yogurt 
#crumble #figs #figjam #palestinianfood #palestinian #palestiniankitchen #summer #summerdessert #fruit #تين

It’s G I V E A W A Y time!

Nothing brings me more hope and joy than finding ways to connect with my home in Palestine. From my hometown in Palestine all the way to Chicago in collaboration with my own mother and @handmadepalestine I bring you a taste of home. 
Amal أَمل, meaning Hope in Arabic, is a special project directed by my own mother fadwa in ArRam Palestine. where women who do not have the opportunity to pursue their education or generate income are professionally trained in creating leather and embroidery tatreez products to sustain their families’ livelihoods and create a hopeful future. @amal.workshop 

These kitchen tea towels are hand stitched with traditional Palestinian tatreez by women from Amal Workshop. The designs were inspired by the work of Tania Nasir in archiving and celebrating traditional tatreez falahi- hand embroidered with traditional motifs from Palestinian cities. The motifs on this set are from Jaffa يافا and Hebron الخليل 
The cotton waffle fabric is sourced from Nazareth and stitching is done by hand from women at Amal Workshop.

We are thrilled to finally bring to you the best ever cotton waffle tea towels hand stitched by palestinian women from @amal.workshop in ArRam Palestine. I’m hopes it brightens your kitchen and give you a taste of my home in Palestine.

We are giving away a set of towels for 
F R E E. To enter: please do all 4 to qualify: 

1. LIKE this post
2. Be sure you follow @almondandfig and @handmadepalestine @amal.workshop on Instagram
3. Tag 3 friends AND 
4. Share this post on your story (be sure to tag us and DM a screen shot to @handmadepalestine 

Cut off for entry is Saturday 2 September midnight EST. We’ll announce the winner this Sunday via our story.

Important Note: We’ll ship to you for free if you are in the US but if you are anywhere else in this beautiful world, you are responsible for shipping costs and customs. 

whether you win or not, go shopping today and support our women artisans in Palestine! Link in bio.

Weekend Breakfast in Palestine is elaborate. It is a feast and is definitely not something you eat in a rush. It is a time to gather together with the whole family, sharing laughter and memories over food. Palestinian breakfast is mostly savory, loaded with a wide variety of foods with various textures, colors and flavors. It is a meal loaded with goodness and will truly set you up for the whole day.

Have you already had breakfast? 
How about a long Palestinian Breakfast? Mai @almondandfig shows us how to spend quality time with family and friends over a shared meal on the weekends.
•
•
•
•
#breakfast #palestinian #palestinianfood #mediterranean #themediterraneanlifestyle #qualitytime #familytime #friends #brunch #brunchtime #weekend #feast #mediterraneanlifestyle #mediterraneanlife #slowdown #relaxtime #socialising #foodie #ilovefood #flavors #cooking #eating #onmytable #onmyplate #breakfastideas #breakfasttime #breakfastlover

Fig oil FIGcaccia 

I try to grow plants that remind me of Home , of my Teta and sidos garden in Palestine; olives, figs and lemon trees. 

You see I live in Chicago, fig, olives and lemon trees don’t necessarily thrive under the harsh Midwest winters and short summers

before my Teta passed away I would FaceTime her to show off my garden, and she would laugh at my leafy jungle and she would say “يا ستي you’re wasting your money on leaves” and would giggle away

so I found a way to make the leaves an ingredient I could use and remember her by. I grow the leaves but I buy the figs because these beauties will never ripen before we are knee deep in icy-snow. 
And I know that my grandmother is probably giggling away at the thought of this fig oil FIGcaccia #missherforever #figs #foccacia

يسعد صباحك يا حلو 🎶 
Good morning sunshine, one of my mom’s must play in the morning songs by the famous Lebanese legend~ Fairuz 

Growing up my mother always made cake for the weekend, most of the time it was a simple tea cake to have with Sunday mornings coffee. It’s always placed right in its baking pan on the counter covered with a checkered kitchen towel. 

𝐕𝐢𝐛𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐩𝐥𝐮𝐦 & 𝐫𝐨𝐬𝐞  𝐒𝐟𝐨𝐮𝐟 𝐜𝐚𝐤𝐞 

Sfouf is a Lebanese turmeric semolina cake, a recipe I learned and adapted from my sweet friend Nadia  @potsnbites Sfouf in arabic literally mean “rows”, I brightened this simple subtly sweet cake with the last of the plums of the season and rose water. 
Make a cake, play your fav songs, and leave the cake on the kitchen counter to enjoy all week long.

*this beautiful handmade bowl is a gift from my sister @zaina.s.k she bought it for me from an Armenian ceramic shop in the old city of Jerusalem

I’ve lived and witnessed much in my life, having been born and raised in Palestine. I’ve experienced firsthand the ongoing Israeli oppression, injustice, dehumanization, racism, and discrimination. 
My grandparents lived through the Nakba of 1948 and they are probably weeping in heaven at another genocide unfolding before our eyes in Gaza.

A genocide supported and justified by the Western media, countries and the U.S.

Children write their names on their hands before they sleep so they can be identified in case they die. 

Buildings are collapsing on their own residents. 

Rockets are falling and killing Children, infants, and the unborn.

Mothers, Children, elderly, grandparents, people with disabilities, men and women are trapped under the rubbles.

Hospitals, homes, schools, ambulances, mosques, and churches are all targeted, leaving no safe place. 

Israel has cut off water, food, and electricity supplies, and it’s preventing outside aid from entering Gaza.

Israel told them to evacuate
Palestinians in Gaza can’t get out. Israel controls all the boarders. The Israeli occupation surrounded Gaza by a militarized -controlled fence with high surveillance from every side

Tents are being set up once again for the displaced, with over 1 million people becoming refugees yet again. 

Hospitals are running out of medicine
Kids body parts are being stitched with no anesthesia 
Vinegar is used as antiseptic 
and unimaginable conditions force surgeries to be performed on the floor and in hospital corridors.

Gaza is running out of body bags 

In the face of all this, there is a haunting silence

Terrified to what we’ll wake up to in Gaza. 
Speak up NOW.

Dear sitti, please forgive us 

In 1948, at the age of 15, Anaam was displaced from her village during the Nakba due to the massacres committed by Zionist gangs against Palestinian civilians in neighboring villages.

In 2023, at 90 years old, the isr@eli occupation destroyed her home in northern Gaza, forcing her to be displaced once again. Barely able to stand on her feet, she was forced to walk south for more than 5 kilometers thirsty, and hungry amidst the sound of bombings and mass destruction💔💚🖤🤍 سامحينا يا ستي

The wrinkles on your face tell stories of Palestine older than the state of isr@el

Elham Farah, Gaza’s oldest Music Teacher, was KILLED. A cherished friend to our family, my husband fondly remembers her beautiful, kind spirit and the wonderful accordion music she shared during visits to the West Bank when Gazan Christians were permitted to celebrate Christmas and Easter with the church there. She was tragically shot on Sunday and killed on Monday, 11/13, at the age of 84 by the Isr@elî  Occüp@tion  forces outside the Holy Family Church in northern Gaza.

Known as Miss Elham by many, she sought refuge inside the church for some time. On Sunday, stepping outside to check if her house had survived the bombings, she was shot in the leg and fell to the ground. Attempts to rescue her were hindered by gunfire each time people ventured out. Activists circulated a tweet from Farah’s niece, appealing for intervention.

Tragically, Elham lay in the street all night, bleeding, cold, and alone, with no one able to help her. No ambulances were allowed to reach her in al Rimal neighborhood near Al-Shifa Hospital in the northern Gaza Strip. She bled to death, adding to the grim tally of the 12,000 Palestinians massacred in Gaza.
Sleep in peace, Miss Elham. Play the accordion for all the children in heaven 💔

From the north of Gaza to the presumed safety of the south, every step seems to be a gamble with fate as homes crumble and lives disintegrate under isr@hell relentless bombing and killing campaign. 

The world witnesses a live genocide unfolding in real time, and silence becomes an act of complicity.

A Gazan mother’s deep قهر

Amidst the echoes of a lullaby unsung,
A bed sheet stained with her son’s blood, tightly clung.
She rocks him back and forth with heavy sighs. Her body shakes, asking her child angel for forgiveness with tearful eyes.
So much grief, how will healing ever start?
For a Gazan mother holding her massacred child in her heart. Tiny footsteps echo in her memory’s solemn lane, A love so profound, an enduring pain.
A world so cruel to a Gazan mother 💔

In Rafah, a Palestinian city in southern Gaza, when a house became a target by Israeli relentless bombardment, this woman rushed to the hospital, scouring the wounded. Discovering her injured brother, she embraced him, but her search persisted, fueled by the desperate hope to find her son. In the end, her quest led her to the painful truth – her son, among the martyrs.

Reporting & 🎥 @ahmedhijazee

“We, high above the skies, are building another city, doctors without patients or blood, teachers without overcrowded classrooms and aren’t yelling at their students, new families without pains or sorrows, journalists capturing heaven, and poets writing about eternal love – all from Gaza, all of them. In heaven, there is a new Gaza without siege forming now.”

Hiba Abu Nada is a novelist, poet, and educator. Her novel Oxygen is Not for the Dead won the Sharjah Award for Arab Creativity in 2017.
Hiba wrote this on October 15th days before she was killed in her home in south Gaza by an Isrxfli brutal raid on Oct. 20th, 2023. She was 32 years old.
Rest in eternal power Hiba 💔🖤🤍💚

No joy to the world
As 28,000 Palestinians in Gaza fall victim to cold-blooded killings
No joy to the world
When 1.9 million Palestinians endure displacement, thirst, cold, and hunger
No joy to the world
As pregnant Marys give birth among the rubble in tents, enduring C-sections without anesthesia
No joy to the world
When Bethlehem, Christ’s birthplace, is enclosed by concrete walls, armed checkpoints, and machine guns
No joy to the world
Over 11,000 of Gaza’s children are killed,
No joy to the world
Beneath the rubble, the lifeless bodies of children and families lay
No joy to the world
Santa arrives in Gaza, there are no children to embrace.
No joy to the world
As silent night is woke by the constant roar of bombings
No joy to the world
A weathered tree stands amid the rubble, devoid of lights and decor
No joy to the world 
Gaza’s churches are destroyed by US made bombs and no place to pray 
No joy to the world
Until we grasp the true meaning of Christmas—Jesus’ birth 
No joy to the world 
Until a permanent ceasefire, and an end to the oppression and all the pain. 
No merry Christmas as usual during an ongoing genocide.

“ ليس بضعة مني ، حمزة كان كُلّي ، روح الروح “ 
“Hamza was not part of me. He was all of me, soul of my soul.” Wael Al-Dahdouh 

Today, Israel killed Hamza al-Dahdooh, 27 yrs old and the son of Al Jazeera correspondent in Gaza, Wael al-Dahdooh.  Another heartbreaking day in Gaza as another journalist is deliberately targeted. This is Hamza’s last social media story, he was covering the aftermath of an Israeli air strike when their vehicle was directly targeted in khan younis (southern Gaza) an area that was deemed safe, hamza and his colleague mustafa were killed, no where is safe in Gaza. 
In the past few weeks Israel had killed Wael al-Dahdooh’s wife, his 15-year old son Mahmoud, his 7-year old daughter Sham, and his grandson Adam in a bombing of their home in October, and now his oldest son. Israel attempted to target him with a drone strike, he survived but his colleague Samer was killed. Al-Dahdooh family is one of many in Gaza who are suffering an enormous pain, suffering and loss. The journalist family shared with the world stories of the genocide in Gaza until they became the story themselves. 
In hamza’s last post he tells his father to not despair and to be patient. While the world remains silent and complicit in the genocide, over 23,000 Palestinians including almost 10,000 children & 111 journalists are killed by Israel in 90 days. 
Rest in Peace, Hamza
